In early 1997 the Russian government approved in principle the now-common model of electricity sector reform: vertically separating generation, transmission, and distribution; introducing competition where possible; strengthening the regulation of functions less amenable to competition; and divesting government ownership. This Note outlines the challenges posed by these characteristics and reports on reform achievements so far.
